questiontext.text:
Cylindrical polar coordinates

In cylindrical polar coordinates \((\rho,\phi,z)\), the three unit vectors are \(\underline{\hat{\rho}}\), \(\underline{\hat{\phi}}\) and \(\underline{\hat{z}}\) (see Figure 20(b) on page 38) with scale factors
\(\qquad\displaystyle h_{\rho}=1\), \(h_{\phi} = \rho\), \(h_z=1\).
The quantities \(\rho\) and \(\phi\) are related to \(x\) and \(y\) by \(x=\rho \cos \phi\) and \(y=\rho \sin \phi\). The unit vectors are \(\underline{\hat{\rho}}=\cos \phi \underline{i}+\sin \phi \underline{j}\) and \(\underline{\hat{\phi}}=-\sin \phi\underline{i}+\cos \phi\underline{j}\). In cylindrical polar coordinates,
grad \(\displaystyle f = {\underline \nabla} f = \frac{\partial f}{\partial \rho} \underline{\hat{\rho}} + \frac{1}{\rho} \frac{\partial f}{\partial \phi} \underline{\hat{\phi}} + \frac{\partial f}{\partial z} \underline{\hat{z}}\)
The scale factor \(\rho\) is necessary in the \(\phi\)-component because the derivatives with respect to \(\phi\) are distorted by the distance from the axis \(\rho = 0\). If \(\quad\underline{F} = F_{\rho} \underline{\hat{\rho}} + F_{\phi} \underline{\hat{\phi}} + F_z \underline{\hat{z}}\quad\) then
div \(\displaystyle \underline{F} = {\underline \nabla} \cdot \underline{F} = \frac{1}{\rho} \left[ \frac{\partial}{\partial \rho}(\rho F_{\rho}) + \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi}(F_{\phi}) + \frac{\partial}{\partial z}(\rho F_z) \right]\)
curl \(\displaystyle \underline{F} = {\underline \nabla} \times \displaystyle \underline{F} = \frac{1}{\rho} \left|\begin{array}{ccc} \underline{\hat{\rho}} & \rho \underline{\hat{\phi}} & \underline{\hat{z}} \\ \\ \displaystyle \frac{\partial}{\partial \rho} & \displaystyle \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi} & \displaystyle \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \\ \\ F_{\rho} & \rho F_{\phi} & F_z \end{array} \right|\).

Example

Working in cylindrical polar coordinates, find \({\underline \nabla} f\) for \(f = \rho^2 + z^2\)

Solution

If \(f= \rho^2 + z^2\) then \(\displaystyle \frac{\partial f}{\partial \rho} = 2 \rho\),\(\displaystyle \frac{\partial f}{\partial \phi} = 0\) and\(\displaystyle \frac{\partial f}{\partial z} = 2 z\) so \({\underline \nabla} f = 2 \rho \underline{\hat{\rho}} + 2 z \underline{\hat{z}}\).

Example

Working in cylindrical polar coordinates find

  1. \({\underline \nabla}f\) for \(f=\rho^3\sin\phi\)
  2. Show that the result for (a) is consistent with that found working in Cartesian coordinates.

Solution

  1. If \(f = \rho^3 \sin \phi\) then \(\displaystyle \frac{\partial f}{\partial \rho} = 3 \rho^2 \sin \phi\), \(\displaystyle \frac{\partial f}{\partial \phi} = \rho^3 \cos \phi\) and \(\displaystyle \frac{\partial f}{\partial z} = 0\) and hence, \({\underline \nabla} f = 3 \rho^2 \sin \phi \underline{\hat{\rho}} + \rho^2 \cos \phi \underline{\hat{\phi}}\).
  2. \(f = \rho^3\sin\phi =\rho^2 \rho \sin \phi = (x^2 + y^2)y = x^2 y + y^3\) so \({\underline \nabla} f = 2 x y \underline{i} + (x^2 + 3 y^2) \underline{j}\).
    Using cylindrical polar coordinates, from (a) we have \begin{eqnarray*} {\underline \nabla} f &=& 3 \rho^2 \sin \phi \underline{\hat{\rho}} + \rho^3 \cos \phi \underline{\hat{\phi}} \\ &=& 3 \rho^2 \sin \phi (\cos \phi \underline{i} + \sin \phi \underline{j}) + \rho^2 \cos \phi (- \sin \phi \underline{i} + \cos \phi \underline{j}) \\ &=& \left[3 \rho^2 \sin \phi \cos \phi - \rho^2 \sin \phi \cos \phi \right]\underline{i} + \left[3 \rho^2 \sin^2 \phi + \rho^2 \cos^2 \phi \right]\underline{j} \\ &=& \left[2 \rho^2 \sin \phi \cos \phi \right]\underline{i} + \left[3 \rho^2 \sin^2 \phi + \rho^2 \cos^2 \phi \right]\underline{j}= 2 x y \underline{i} + (3y^2 + x^2) \underline{j}\qquad\qquad \end{eqnarray*} So the results using Cartesian and cylindrical polar coordinates are consistent.

Example

Find \({\underline \nabla} \cdot \underline{F}\) for \(\underline{F} = F_{\rho} \underline{\hat{\rho}} + F_{\phi} \underline{\hat{\phi}} + F_z \underline{\hat{z}} = \rho^3 \underline{\hat{\rho}} + \rho z \underline{\hat{\phi}} + \rho z \sin \phi \underline{\hat{z}}\). Show that the results are consistent with those found using Cartesian coordinates.

Solution

Here, \(F_{\rho} = \rho^3\), \(F_{\phi} = \rho z\) and \(F_z= \rho z \sin \phi\) so \begin{eqnarray*}{\underline \nabla} \cdot \underline{F} &=& \frac{1}{\rho} \left[ \frac{\partial}{\partial \rho}(\rho F_{\rho}) +\frac{\partial}{\partial \phi}(F_{\phi}) + \frac{\partial}{\partial z}(\rho F_z) \right] \\&=& \frac{1}{\rho} \left[ \frac{\partial}{\partial \rho}(\rho^4) + \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi}(\rho z) +\frac{\partial}{\partial z}(\rho^2 z \sin \phi) \right] \\ &=& \frac{1}{\rho} \left[ 4 \rho^3 + 0 + \rho^2 \sin \phi \right]\\ &=& 4 \rho^2 + \rho \sin \phi\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad \end{eqnarray*} Converting to Cartesian coordinates, \begin{eqnarray*} \underline{F} &=& F_{\rho} \underline{\hat{\rho}} + F_{\phi} \underline{\hat{\phi}} + F_z \underline{\hat{z}} = \rho^3 \underline{\hat{\rho}} + \rho z \underline{\hat{\phi}} + \rho z \sin \phi \underline{\hat{z}} \\ &=& \rho^3 (\cos \phi \underline{i} + \sin \phi \underline{j}) + \rho z (-\sin \phi \underline{i} + \cos \phi \underline{j}) + \rho z \sin \phi \underline{k} \\ &=& (\rho^3 \cos \phi - \rho z \sin \phi) \underline{i} + (\rho^3 \sin \phi + \rho z \cos \phi) + \rho z \underline{k} \\ &=& \left[\rho^2 (\rho \cos \phi) - \rho \sin \phi z \right] \underline{i} + \left[ \rho^2 (\rho \sin \phi) + \rho \cos \phi z\right]\underline{j} + \rho \sin \phi z \underline{k} \\ &=& \left[(x^2 + y^2) x - y z \right] \underline{i} + \left[ (x^2 + y^2) y + x z \right]\underline{j} + y z \underline{k} \\ &=& (x^3 + x y^2 - y z ) \underline{i} + ( x^2 y + y^3 + x z )\underline{j} + y z \underline{k}\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad \end{eqnarray*} So \begin{eqnarray*} {\underline \nabla} \cdot \underline{F} &=& \frac{\partial}{\partial x}(x^3 + x y^2 - y z ) + \frac{\partial}{\partial y}(x^2 y + y^3 + x z ) + \frac{\partial}{\partial z}(y z ) \\ &=& (3x^2 + y^2) + (x^2 + 3 y^2) + y = 4 x^2 + 4 y^2 + y\\ &=&4(x^2+y^2)+y \\ &=& 4 \rho^2 + \rho \sin \phi\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad \end{eqnarray*} So \({\underline \nabla} \cdot \underline{F}\) is the same in both coordinate systems.

Example

Find \({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}\) for \(\underline{F} = \rho^2 \underline{\hat{\rho}} + z \sin \phi \underline{\hat{\phi}} + 2 z \cos \phi \underline{\hat{z}}\).

Solution

\begin{eqnarray*} {\underline \nabla} \times \displaystyle \underline{F} &=& \frac{1}{\rho} \left|\begin{array}{ccc} \underline{\hat{\rho}} & \rho \underline{\hat{\phi}} & \underline{\hat{z}} \\ \\ \displaystyle \frac{\partial}{\partial \rho} & \displaystyle \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi} & \displaystyle \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \\ \\ F_{\rho} & \rho F_{\phi} & F_z \end{array} \right| = \frac{1}{\rho}\left|\begin{array}{ccc} \underline{\hat{\rho}} & \rho \underline{\hat{\phi}} & \underline{\hat{z}} \\ \\ \displaystyle \frac{\partial}{\partial \rho} & \displaystyle \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi} & \displaystyle \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \\ \\ \rho^2 & \rho z \sin \phi & 2 z \cos \phi \end{array} \right| \\ &=& \!\frac{1}{\rho} \left[ \underline{\hat{\rho}} \left[ \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi}2 z \cos \phi - \frac{\partial}{\partial z}\rho z \sin \phi \right]\! +\! \rho \underline{\hat{\phi}} \left[ \frac{\partial}{\partial z}\rho^2 - \frac{\partial}{\partial \rho }2 z \cos \phi \right]\! +\! \underline{\hat{z}} \left[ \frac{\partial}{\partial \rho}\rho z \sin \phi - \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi}\rho^2 \right] \right] \\ &=& \frac{1}{\rho} \left[ \underline{\hat{\rho}} (-2 z \sin \phi - \rho \sin \phi ) + \rho \underline{\hat{\phi}} (0) + \underline{\hat{z}} (z \sin \phi) \right] \\ &=& -\frac{(2 z \sin \phi)}{\rho} \underline{\hat{\rho}} + \frac{z \sin \phi}{\rho} \underline{\hat{z}}\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad \end{eqnarray*}

Engineering Example

Divergence of a magnetic field

Introduction A magnetic field \({\underline B}\) must satisfy \({{\underline \nabla}}\cdot {\underline B}=0\). An associated current is given by: \(\qquad\displaystyle {\underline I}=\dfrac{1}{\mu_0}({ {\underline \nabla}}\times{\underline B})\)

Problem in words For the magnetic field (in cylindrical polar coordinates \(\rho,\phi, z)\) \(\displaystyle {\underline B}=B_0\dfrac{\rho}{1+\rho^2}{\underline {\hat\phi}}+\alpha {\underline {\hat z}}\) show that the divergence of \(\underline B\) is zero and find the associated current.

Mathematical statement of problem We must (a) show that \({ {\underline \nabla}}\cdot{\underline B}=0.\) (b) find the current \({\underline I}=\dfrac{1}{\mu_0}({ {\underline \nabla}}\times{\underline B})\)

Mathematical analysis

  1. Express \({\underline B}\) as \((B_{\rho},B_{\phi}, B_z)\); then \[\begin{aligned} {{\underline \nabla}}\cdot {\underline B}&=\dfrac{1}{{\rho}}\left[\dfrac{\partial}{\partial {\rho}}({\rho}B_{\rho}) +\dfrac{\partial }{\partial \phi}(B_{\phi}) +\dfrac{\partial }{\partial z}({\rho}B_z)\right]\\ &=\dfrac{1}{{\rho}}\left[\dfrac{\partial }{\partial {\rho}}(0)+\dfrac{\partial} {\partial\phi}\left(B_0\dfrac{{\rho}}{1+{\rho}^2}\right)+{\rho}\dfrac{\partial}{\partial z}(\alpha)\right]\\ &=\dfrac{1}{{\rho}}[0+0+0]=0\qquad\text{ as required.}\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad \end{aligned}\]
  2. To find the current evaluate \[\begin{aligned} {\underline I}=\dfrac{1}{\mu_0}({ {\underline \nabla}}\times{\underline B})&=\dfrac{1}{\mu_0}\dfrac{1}{{\rho}}\left| \begin{matrix}{\underline {\hat {\rho}}}&{\rho}{\underline {\hat\phi}}&{\underline {\hat z}}\\\\ \dfrac{\partial}{\partial {\rho}}&\dfrac{\partial}{\partial\phi}&\dfrac{\partial}{\partial z}\\\\ B_{\rho}&{\rho}B_{\phi}&B_z \end{matrix}\right|=\left| \begin{matrix}{\underline {\hat {\rho}}}&{\rho}{\underline {\hat\phi}}&{\underline {\hat z}}\\\\ \dfrac{\partial}{\partial {\rho}}&\dfrac{\partial}{\partial\phi}&\dfrac{\partial}{\partial z}\\\\ 0&B_0\dfrac{{\rho}^2}{1+{\rho}^2}&\alpha \end{matrix}\right|\\ &=\dfrac{1}{\mu_0{\rho}}\left[0{\underline {\hat {\rho}}}+0{\rho}{\underline {\hat\phi}}+ B_0\dfrac{\partial}{\partial {\rho}}\left(\dfrac{{\rho}^2}{1+{\rho}^2}\right){\underline {\hat z}}\right]\\\\ &=\dfrac{1}{\mu_0{\rho}}B_0\left[\dfrac{2{\rho}}{(1+{\rho}^2)^2}\right]{\underline {\hat z}}=\dfrac{2B_0}{\mu_0{(1+{\rho}^2)^2}}\;{\underline {\hat z}}\end{aligned}\]

Interpretation The magnetic field is in the form of a helix with the current pointing along its axis. Such an arrangement is often used for the magnetic containment of charged particles in a fusion reactor.

 

Example

A magnetic field \(\underline{B}\) is given by \(\underline{B} = \rho^{-2} \underline{\hat{\phi}} + k \underline{{\hat z}}\). Find \({\underline \nabla} \cdot \underline{B}\) and \({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{B}\).

Solution

\(\displaystyle {\underline \nabla} \cdot \underline{B} = \frac{1}{\rho}\left[\frac{\partial}{\partial \rho}0 + \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi}\rho^{-2} + \frac{\partial}{\partial z}k\rho \right] = \frac{1}{\rho} \left[ 0 + 0 + 0 \right] = 0 \) \(\displaystyle\qquad {\underline \nabla} \times \displaystyle \underline{B} = \frac{1}{\rho} \left|\begin{array}{ccc} \underline{\hat{\rho}} & \rho \underline{\hat{\phi}} & \underline{\hat{z}} \\ \\ \displaystyle \frac{\partial}{\partial \rho} & \displaystyle \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi} & \displaystyle \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \\ \\ B_{\rho} & B_{\phi} & B_z \end{array} \right| = \frac{1}{\rho}\left|\begin{array}{ccc} \underline{\hat{\rho}} & \rho \underline{\hat{\phi}} & \underline{\hat{z}} \\ \\ \displaystyle \frac{\partial}{\partial \rho} & \displaystyle \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi} & \displaystyle \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \\ \\ \rho^{-2} & 0 & k \end{array} \right|\) \(\displaystyle = \underline{0}\)
All magnetic fields satisfy \({{\underline \nabla}}\cdot{\underline B}=0\) i.e. an absence of magnetic monopoles. There is a class of magnetic fields known as potential fields that satisfy \({{\underline \nabla}}\times{\underline B}={\underline 0}\)
